topics.title: The Endowment Effect: Why You Overvalue What You Own

hook.text: Give someone a coffee mug and they'll demand $7 to sell it.

buildup.text: Economists Richard Thaler and Daniel Kahneman tested this with hundreds of students.

discovery.text: The endowment effect: owning something makes it feel more valuable. Possession creates an emotional premium.

twist.text: This is why free trials work so well. Once you 'own' Netflix for a month, canceling feels like losing something real.

climax.text: Rational economics says a mug is worth the same to buyer and seller. Real humans don't work that way.

punchline.text: You value things more just because they're yours.

quiz.question: What is the endowment effect?
options: People buy more when prices drop
People overvalue things simply because they own them

topics.title: Anchoring: The Number That Hijacks Your Brain

hook.text: Spin a wheel that lands on 65, then guess what percentage of African countries are in the UN.

buildup.text: Tversky and Kahneman showed that random numbers influence unrelated estimates. The first number 'anchors' your brain.

discovery.text: Retailers exploit this constantly. A $500 jacket next to a $200 jacket makes the $200 one feel like a bargain.

twist.text: Even experts fall for anchoring. Judges gave longer sentences when a reporter suggested higher numbers before.

climax.text: Your brain doesn't judge value in a vacuum â€” it always needs a reference point, even a meaningless one.

punchline.text: The first number you see controls what you think is fair.

quiz.question: How does anchoring bias affect economic decisions?
options: People always choose the cheapest option
Initial numbers influence subsequent judgments, even when irrelevant

topics.title: Status Quo Bias: The Power of Doing Nothing

hook.text: Countries with opt-out organ donation have 90%+ donors. Opt-in countries: about 15%. Same people, different default.

buildup.text: Status quo bias means people disproportionately stick with whatever the current option is.

discovery.text: Changing requires effort and risk. Staying put feels safe. Our brains treat inaction as the neutral, comfortable choice.

twist.text: Companies exploit this with auto-renewals. Gym memberships, subscriptions, insurance â€” the default is to keep paying.

climax.text: The most powerful economic force isn't persuasion â€” it's setting the default.

punchline.text: The option you don't have to choose is the one most people end up with.

quiz.question: Why do opt-out organ donation countries have far higher rates?
options: People care more about donation there
Status quo bias makes people stick with the default option

topics.title: The Dunning-Kruger Effect in Markets

hook.text: 74% of fund managers believe they are above average at investing. Mathematically, half of them are wrong.

buildup.text: The Dunning-Kruger effect: people with low ability at a task overestimate their skill. Beginners feel most confident.

discovery.text: Novice traders trade more frequently and take bigger risks â€” because they don't know what they don't know.

twist.text: Studies show the more someone trades, the worse they perform. Overconfidence is the most expensive bias in finance.

climax.text: Markets don't reward confidence â€” they reward accuracy. The gap between the two is where fortunes are lost.

punchline.text: The less you know about markets, the more you think you know.

quiz.question: How does the Dunning-Kruger effect manifest in financial markets?
options: Novice investors overestimate their skill and trade too aggressively

topics.title: Hyperbolic Discounting: Why $100 Now Beats $110 Tomorrow

hook.text: Offer someone $100 today or $110 tomorrow â€” most take the $100. Offer $100 in 30 days or $110 in 31 â€” most wait.

buildup.text: Standard economics assumes people discount the future at a constant rate.

discovery.text: Hyperbolic discounting: we overvalue immediate rewards and undervalue future ones, but only when 'now' is involved.

twist.text: This is why people take payday loans at 400% interest. The pain is future; the relief is now. The math doesn't matter.

climax.text: Our brains run on two systems: one wants marshmallows now, the other plans for retirement. They rarely agree.

punchline.text: We're perfectly rational about the future and perfectly impatient about today.

quiz.question: What is hyperbolic discounting?
options: Preferring guaranteed money over risky bets
Disproportionately preferring immediate rewards over slightly larger future ones

topics.title: Loss Aversion: Losses Hurt Twice as Much as Gains Feel Good

hook.text: Finding $100 feels nice. Losing $100 feels devastating. The pain of loss is roughly twice the pleasure of an equal gain.

buildup.text: Kahneman and Tversky discovered that humans aren't wired to weigh gains and losses equally. Losses loom larger.

discovery.text: Investors hold losers too long (avoiding the pain of loss) and sell winners too early (locking in gains).

twist.text: Companies use loss aversion in marketing: 'Don't miss out!' is more powerful than 'Great opportunity!

climax.text: Loss aversion means humans are not optimizers â€” we're protectors. Avoiding loss matters more than seeking gain.

punchline.text: We don't play to win. We play not to lose.

quiz.question: How strong is loss aversion compared to gains?
options: Losses hurt about twice as much as equivalent gains feel good

topics.title: Mental Accounting: The Money in Your Head

hook.text: You won't spend $200 from savings on concert tickets, but you'll happily spend a $200 bonus.

buildup.text: Richard Thaler showed that people treat money differently based on its source, not its actual value.

discovery.text: We create mental 'accounts' â€” rent money, fun money, emergency money.

twist.text: Casinos exploit this. People gamble winnings recklessly because it feels like 'house money' â€” not 'their' money.

climax.text: Mental accounting means money isn't fungible in our minds. Where it came from changes how we spend it.

punchline.text: Every dollar is equal. Your brain just doesn't believe that.

quiz.question: What is mental accounting?
options: Tracking spending in a budget app
Treating money differently based on its source or intended use, not its actual value

topics.title: The Sunk Cost Fallacy: Throwing Good Money After Bad

hook.text: You've watched 90 minutes of a terrible movie. You stay because you've already invested 90 minutes.

buildup.text: Sunk costs are money or time already spent that can't be recovered.

discovery.text: The Concorde jet kept getting funded for decades despite clear evidence it would never be profitable. $5 billion â€” gone.

twist.text: The more we invest, the harder it gets to quit.

climax.text: The sunk cost fallacy is loss aversion in disguise. Quitting means admitting the loss, and our brains can't stand that.

punchline.text: The money is gone whether you stay or leave. Only one choice wastes more.

quiz.question: Why do people fall for the sunk cost fallacy?
options: Abandoning an investment feels like admitting a loss, which triggers loss aversion

topics.title: Confirmation Bias: Seeing What You Want to See

hook.text: Buy a stock and suddenly every positive headline jumps out. Negative news? You scroll right past it.

buildup.text: Confirmation bias means we seek, notice, and remember information that supports our existing beliefs while ignoring.

discovery.text: Investors who research their own stock picks spend 70% of their time on confirming evidence and 30% on disconfirming.

twist.text: Social media amplifies this exponentially.

climax.text: The best investors actively seek evidence against their positions. Fighting confirmation bias is a skill worth millions.

punchline.text: The most dangerous research is the kind that always agrees with you.

quiz.question: How does confirmation bias affect investors?
options: They disproportionately seek and remember information supporting their existing beliefs

topics.title: The Framing Effect: Same Facts, Different Decisions

hook.text: 'This surgery has a 90% survival rate' vs. 'This surgery has a 10% mortality rate.' Same fact.

buildup.text: Tversky and Kahneman found that how information is presented â€” the frame.

discovery.text: Supermarkets label meat '95% lean' instead of '5% fat.' Insurance companies frame premiums as 'protection' not 'cost.'

twist.text: Doctors make different treatment recommendations depending on whether outcomes are framed as survival or mortality.

climax.text: We don't respond to reality â€” we respond to how reality is described. The frame is the hidden persuader.

punchline.text: Change the words and you change the choice.

quiz.question: What does the framing effect demonstrate?
options: How information is presented changes decisions, even when the underlying facts are identical

topics.title: Prospect Theory: Why We Gamble with Losses

hook.text: You'll refuse a fair coin flip for $1,000 â€” too risky. But if you're already down $1,000, you'll flip to get it back.

buildup.text: Kahneman and Tversky's prospect theory showed we're risk-averse with gains but risk-seeking with losses.

discovery.text: When winning, we play safe to protect gains. When losing, we gamble recklessly hoping to break even.

twist.text: This explains why traders double down on losing positions. The loss puts them in 'gambling mode' â€” chasing recovery.

climax.text: Prospect theory won Kahneman the Nobel Prize.

punchline.text: Losing money doesn't make us careful. It makes us reckless.

quiz.question: According to prospect theory, how do people behave when facing losses?
options: They become risk-seeking, gambling to recover losses

topics.title: Reference Points: The Invisible Ruler in Your Head

hook.text: A $70,000 salary feels amazing if you expected $50,000. The same salary feels crushing if you expected $90,000.

buildup.text: Prospect theory says we don't evaluate outcomes in absolute terms.

discovery.text: Homeowners refuse to sell below their purchase price, even in a crash.

twist.text: Bronze Olympic medalists are happier than silver medalists. Silver compares to gold (loss).

climax.text: Happiness isn't about what you have â€” it's about what you expected to have. Economics is always relative.

punchline.text: Your satisfaction depends on where you thought you'd be, not where you are.

quiz.question: Why are bronze Olympic medalists often happier than silver medalists?
options: Silver medalists compare up to gold (loss) while bronze compares down to no medal (gain)

topics.title: The Certainty Effect: Why We Hate Probabilities

hook.text: Most people prefer a guaranteed $800 over a 90% chance of $1,000.

buildup.text: The certainty effect: people overweight certain outcomes and underweight merely probable ones.

discovery.text: This is why people buy overpriced insurance for cheap electronics.

twist.text: But flip it: a certain loss of $800 or 90% chance of losing $1,000? Now people gamble. Certainty repels us with losses.

climax.text: We crave certainty for gains and avoid certainty for losses. The asymmetry makes us predictably irrational.

punchline.text: A sure thing feels infinitely better than almost sure.

quiz.question: What is the certainty effect?
options: People prefer guaranteed outcomes for gains even when gambles have higher expected value
People always choose the risky option
People are equally rational with all probabilities

topics.title: Loss Framing in Insurance: Selling Fear

hook.text: Americans spend $300 billion yearly on insurance they'll probably never use.

buildup.text: Insurance companies don't sell coverage. They sell the elimination of worry.

discovery.text: Loss aversion makes people pay huge premiums to avoid small risks.

twist.text: Extended warranties have profit margins of 50-70%.

climax.text: Insurance is prospect theory in action: we'll overpay for certainty to avoid the psychological pain of a possible loss.

punchline.text: The insurance industry runs on the gap between what we fear and what actually.

quiz.question: Why do extended warranties have such high profit margins?
options: Loss aversion makes people overpay to eliminate even small risks of loss

topics.title: The Disposition Effect: Selling Winners Too Soon

hook.text: Investors are 50% more likely to sell a stock that went up than one that went down.

buildup.text: The disposition effect: investors realize gains too quickly and hold losses too long.

discovery.text: Selling winners locks in the pleasure of a gain. Holding losers avoids the pain of admitting a mistake.

twist.text: Studies show the stocks investors sold (winners) outperformed the stocks they kept (losers) by 3.4% over the next year.

climax.text: Prospect theory predicts this perfectly: risk-averse with gains (sell), risk-seeking with losses (hold).

punchline.text: We sell our flowers and water our weeds.

quiz.question: What is the disposition effect?
options: Investors sell winning stocks too early and hold losing stocks too long

topics.title: Default Options: The Choice You Don't Make

hook.text: When the US switched 401(k) retirement plans from opt-in to automatic enrollment, participation jumped from 49% to 86%.

buildup.text: People didn't change their minds about saving. They just didn't bother changing the default. Inertia did the work.

discovery.text: Defaults exploit status quo bias â€” the tendency to do nothing.

twist.text: Software companies use dark patterns â€” pre-checked boxes for newsletters, auto-added insurance at checkout.

climax.text: Whoever designs the default designs the outcome.

punchline.text: The most influential decision-maker is the person who sets the default.

quiz.question: Why did automatic 401(k) enrollment dramatically increase participation?
options: Status quo bias meant most people simply accepted the default option to enroll

topics.title: Libertarian Paternalism: Thaler's Nudge Philosophy

hook.text: What if you could improve people's decisions without taking away their freedom? That's the radical idea behind.

buildup.text: Richard Thaler and Cass Sunstein argued governments can design choices that steer people toward better outcomes.

discovery.text: Put fruit at eye level in cafeterias and junk food in the back. Sales of fruit rise 25%. Nobody's freedom is restricted.

twist.text: Critics say nudges are manipulation. If the government designs your choices, is your decision really free?

climax.text: Thaler won the 2017 Nobel Prize for showing that small design changes in choice environments can transform economic.

punchline.text: A nudge changes behavior without changing the menu.

quiz.question: What is libertarian paternalism?
options: Designing choice environments to steer better decisions while preserving freedom

topics.title: Choice Overload: When More Options Paralyze

hook.text: A grocery store offered 24 jam samples and sold 3 jars. Another day, 6 samples sold 30 jars.

buildup.text: Sheena Iyengar's jam study revealed the paradox of choice: too many options create anxiety and decision paralysis.

discovery.text: With 24 options, people enjoy browsing but can't commit. With 6, the decision feels manageable. Less is more for sales.

twist.text: Companies with 50+ product variations often see lower revenue than competitors with 10.

climax.text: Freedom of choice has a tipping point. Past it, more options don't empower â€” they overwhelm.

punchline.text: The best way to sell more is to offer less.

quiz.question: What did Sheena Iyengar's jam study demonstrate?
options: Too many options cause decision paralysis and reduce purchases

topics.title: IKEA Effect: Love What You Build

hook.text: People who assemble IKEA furniture value it 63% more than identical pre-assembled furniture. Effort creates love.

buildup.text: Dan Ariely tested this: people who built origami valued their ugly creations almost as highly as expert origami.

discovery.text: When we invest labor, we invest identity. The thing we made becomes an extension of ourselves â€” and therefore precious.

twist.text: Betty Crocker cake mixes originally required just adding water. Sales were poor.

climax.text: The IKEA effect explains why DIY, cooking, and crafting feel rewarding. The labor is the product, not just the result.

punchline.text: We don't love things because they're valuable.

quiz.question: What does the IKEA effect demonstrate?
options: People place higher value on things they helped create or assemble
Cheap products feel expensive after assembly

topics.title: Decoy Pricing: The Option That Exists to Be Ignored

hook.text: A magazine offered: digital $59, print $125, print+digital $125.

buildup.text: Dan Ariely found the middle option was a decoy. Remove it, and most people chose digital.

discovery.text: Decoy pricing adds a strategically inferior option that makes the target option look superior by comparison.

twist.text: Movie theaters use this: small $5, medium $7.50, large $8. The medium exists to make the large look like a bargain.

climax.text: We don't evaluate options in isolation. We evaluate them against each other.

punchline.text: The option you're not supposed to pick is there to make you pick the expensive.

quiz.question: How does decoy pricing work?
options: Adding a strategically inferior option that makes the target option look like a better deal

topics.title: Herd Behavior: Following the Financial Crowd

hook.text: In 1999, taxi drivers were giving stock tips. In 2021, teenagers on Reddit moved GameStop's price 1,500%.

buildup.text: Herd behavior: people copy others' decisions, especially under uncertainty. If everyone's buying, it must be good.

discovery.text: Herding creates bubbles. Prices rise not because of value but because of imitation.

twist.text: Herding also causes crashes. When the first sellers panic, others follow.

climax.text: Markets are information aggregators â€” unless everyone's copying each other.

punchline.text: In markets, the crowd is often right â€” until the moment it's catastrophically.

quiz.question: How does herd behavior contribute to financial bubbles?
options: People copy others' buying decisions, inflating prices beyond fundamental value

topics.title: Social Proof: Because Everyone Else Is Doing It

hook.text: Hotels that say '75% of guests reuse towels' get 26% more towel reuse than hotels that just ask.

buildup.text: Social proof: when uncertain, we look at what others do and assume it's correct.

discovery.text: Amazon reviews, bestseller lists, '1,000 people are viewing this' â€” all social proof.

twist.text: Social proof can be faked. Paid reviews, manufactured waiting lists.

climax.text: We evolved in small tribes where copying others was smart.

punchline.text: We buy what others buy because deciding is exhausting.

quiz.question: Why does social proof work as a persuasion tool?
options: Under uncertainty, humans instinctively follow others' behavior as a decision shortcut

topics.title: Fairness and the Ultimatum Game

hook.text: I have $100 to split with you. I offer you $1 and keep $99.

buildup.text: Rationally, you should accept $1 â€” it's better than $0. But experiments show people reject offers below $20-$30.

discovery.text: Brain scans show unfair offers activate the same region as physical disgust. Injustice literally makes us feel sick.

twist.text: Chimpanzees also reject unfair splits. Fairness isn't learned â€” it's wired into primate brains by evolution.

climax.text: Economics assumed we maximize money. The ultimatum game proves we maximize fairness â€” even at personal cost.

punchline.text: We'd rather have nothing than accept something unfair.

quiz.question: What does the ultimatum game reveal about economic behavior?
options: People reject unfair offers even at personal cost, prioritizing fairness over profit

topics.title: Conspicuous Consumption: Spending to Signal Status

hook.text: A plain white T-shirt costs $5. The same shirt with a luxury logo costs $500.

buildup.text: Economist Thorstein Veblen noticed in 1899 that the wealthy buy expensive things specifically because they're expensive.

discovery.text: Veblen goods violate basic economics: higher prices increase demand. A cheaper Rolex would sell fewer watches, not more.

twist.text: Social media amplified conspicuous consumption to all income levels.

climax.text: Much of consumption isn't about utility â€” it's about identity.

punchline.text: We don't buy luxury products. We buy the story they tell others about us.

quiz.question: What are Veblen goods?
options: Products where higher prices increase demand because they signal status

topics.title: Reciprocity Bias: The Free Sample Trap

hook.text: A waiter gives you a free mint and tips increase 3%. Two mints? 14%. A personalized mint? 23%.

buildup.text: Reciprocity is deeply hardwired: when someone gives us something, we feel compelled to give something back.

discovery.text: Costco's free samples generate $5.8 billion in additional sales yearly.

twist.text: The Hare Krishna movement funded itself by giving flowers at airports.

climax.text: Reciprocity isn't generosity â€” it's a transaction our brains process automatically.

punchline.text: Nothing is more expensive than something that's free.

quiz.question: Why do free samples dramatically increase sales?
options: People discover new products they like
Reciprocity bias creates a subconscious obligation to buy after receiving something free

topics.title: Behavioral Finance: When Markets Go Crazy

hook.text: If markets were rational, there would be no bubbles, no crashes, and no day traders losing their savings.

buildup.text: Behavioral finance combines psychology with economics to explain why markets deviate from efficient market theory.

discovery.text: Robert Shiller predicted both the dot-com crash and the 2008 housing crisis using behavioral indicators like.

twist.text: Shiller and Eugene Fama (who believes markets ARE efficient) shared the 2013 Nobel Prize.

climax.text: Markets are mostly efficient, occasionally insane.

punchline.text: Markets are rational â€” until humans are involved.

quiz.question: What does behavioral finance study?
options: How psychological biases cause markets to deviate from rational efficiency
How central banks set interest rates

topics.title: Behavioral Economics in Public Policy

hook.text: The UK created a 'Nudge Unit' in 2010. Small behavioral tweaks saved the government over Â£300 million in three years.

buildup.text: Changing tax letters to say 'Most people in your area have paid' increased on-time payments by 15%.

discovery.text: Simplifying forms, using plain language, and sending timely reminders improved everything from tax compliance to.

twist.text: Over 200 governments worldwide now have behavioral insights teams. Nudges are the cheapest policy tool ever discovered.

climax.text: Understanding human irrationality isn't just academic â€” it's the most cost-effective way to improve public services.

punchline.text: The cheapest way to change behavior is to understand it.

quiz.question: How did the UK's Nudge Unit improve tax payments?
options: Used social proof by telling people most neighbors had already paid

topics.title: Why We Can't Save: The Psychology of Retirement

hook.text: Half of American adults have less than $10,000 saved for retirement. They know they should save more. They just can't.

buildup.text: Hyperbolic discounting makes future-you feel like a stranger.

discovery.text: Thaler's 'Save More Tomorrow' program asks people to commit now to saving more from future raises. Enrollment: 78%.

twist.text: Participants in Save More Tomorrow increased savings from 3.5% to 13.

climax.text: You can't fix irrationality with willpower. You fix it by designing systems that make the irrational choice harder.

punchline.text: The best savings plan tricks you into saving.

quiz.question: Why is Thaler's 'Save More Tomorrow' program effective?
options: People commit to future savings increases, avoiding the present-bias pain of losing current income

topics.title: The Hot Hand Fallacy: Streaks in Random Data

hook.text: A basketball player hits five shots in a row. Commentators say they have a 'hot hand.' Statisticians say it's random.

buildup.text: Tversky studied 76ers games and found no evidence that making one shot increased the probability of making the next.

discovery.text: Our brains are pattern-seeking machines. We see streaks in randomness because evolution rewarded pattern recognition.

twist.text: Investors chase 'hot' funds â€” those with recent high returns.

climax.text: The hot hand fallacy costs investors billions yearly. We keep betting on streaks in data that has no memory.

punchline.text: Past performance doesn't predict the future.

quiz.question: What is the hot hand fallacy?
options: Believing that random streaks will continue, like assuming a winning fund will keep winning

topics.title: Nudging Retirement Savings: The Power of Defaults

hook.text: When companies auto-enroll employees in 401(k) plans, participation jumps from 49% to 86%.

buildup.text: Richard Thaler showed that people intend to save but procrastinate.

discovery.text: The Save More Tomorrow program lets workers commit future raises to savings. They never feel a pay cut.

twist.text: Critics say nudges are manipulation. Thaler argues every system has a default â€” why not pick the one that helps people?

climax.text: Defaults prove that how you present a choice matters as much as the choice itself. Architecture shapes outcomes.

punchline.text: The best retirement plan is the one you never have to choose.

quiz.question: What happens when companies auto-enroll employees in 401(k) plans?
